Question Text: Which of the following terms describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and is delivered to multiple devices on the LAN? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Broadcast address
b. Multicast address
c. IP address
d. MAC address
e. Unicast address
LLM Explanation: Broadcast and multicast addresses are the two types of Ethernet addresses that can send a single frame that is delivered to multiple devices on a LAN. A broadcast address (FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF) sends the frame to all devices, while a multicast address sends the frame to a specific group of devices that have subscribed to that multicast group. The other options - IP address, MAC address, and unicast address - refer to addresses used for delivering frames to a single specific device.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: ___________ is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision.
Choices:
a. CSMA/CD
b. CSMA/CA
c. TCP/IP
d. TCP/UDP
LLM Explanation: CSMA/CD (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection) is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision. When a collision is detected, both devices stop transmitting, wait a random amount of time, and then retry the transmission.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/5241-csma-cd.html']

Question Text: Ethernet standard ___________ BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling.
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet standard that defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling is 1000BASE-T. The number 1000 represents the data transfer rate of 1000 Mbps or 1 Gbps. 10BASE-T and 100BASE-TX are older Ethernet standards that support 10 Mbps and 100 Mbps respectively over UTP cabling.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Working Group', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gigabit_Ethernet']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The preamble field in the Ethernet frame header allows devices to synchronize their receiver clocks. It consists of a 56-bit pattern of alternating 1s and 0s that enables the receiving devices to synchronize their clocks with the sender's clock, ensuring proper reception and interpretation of the frame.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'IEEE 802.3 Ethernet standard documentation']

Question Text: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the ____________ IP address is in a different subnet than the host.
Choices:
a. Source
b. Destination
c. Unicast
d. Broadcast
LLM Explanation: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the destination IP address is in a different subnet than the host. When a host needs to communicate with another device on a different network, it forwards the packets to its default gateway, which then routes the packets to the appropriate destination network.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 16: Fundamentals of IP Version 4 Addressing and Routing', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens, Chapter 2: Link Layer']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Application TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol in the TCP/IP model. It is used for sending and receiving email messages between servers. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and IP (Internet Protocol) reside in the transport and network layers, respectively, while Ethernet is a data link layer protocol.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Transport TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: The Transport layer of the TCP/IP model is responsible for end-to-end communication between applications. The two main protocols in this layer are TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP (User Datagram Protocol). TCP provides reliable, connection-oriented transmission, while UDP offers a connectionless, best-effort service. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an Application layer protocol, Ethernet operates at the Data Link layer, and IP (Internet Protocol) is a Network layer protocol.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'CISCO Official Cert Guide: CCNA 200-301 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: The Internet Protocol (IP) resides in the Internet layer of the TCP/IP architecture model. IP is responsible for addressing hosts and routing datagrams (packets) from a source host to the destination host across one or more IP networks. The other choices reside in different layers: SMTP is an Application layer protocol, TCP is a Transport layer protocol, and Ethernet is a Network Access layer protocol.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of TCP/IP Transport and Applications - Cisco Press', 'TCP/IP Overview - https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13769-5.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Data Link & Physical TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: Ethernet is a protocol that resides in the Data Link and Physical layers of the TCP/IP architecture. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol, TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a transport layer protocol, and IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer protocol.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols is used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network?
Choices:
a. ping
b. ARP
c. DHCP
d. DNS
LLM Explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) is used by a device to learn the MAC address associated with an IP address on the same network. When a device needs to communicate with another device on the local network, it uses ARP to broadcast a request to all devices, asking for the MAC address of the device with the specific IP address. The device with that IP address responds with its MAC address, allowing communication to occur.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 5: Fundamentals of IPv4 Addressing and Routing', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13718-5.html']

Question Text: If the devices below were connected with UTP Ethernet cables, which pairs of devices would require a straight-through cable? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Router and PC
b. Switch and PC
c. Hub and switch
d. Router and hub
LLM Explanation: A straight-through Ethernet cable is used when connecting devices of different types, such as a router to a PC or a switch to a PC. The wiring is straight through, meaning each pin on one end is connected to the same pin on the other end. Choices 'a' (router and PC) and 'b' (switch and PC) require a straight-through cable because they involve connecting dissimilar devices. Choices 'c' (hub and switch) and 'd' (router and hub) connect similar devices, which typically use a crossover cable instead.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/21223-cable-connection-21223.html']
SM - Description: Correct concept but wrong facts (e.g. router and PC being dissimilar)

Question Text: Which of the following protocols are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. TCP
b. HTTP
c. Ethernet
d. PPP
e. SMTP
f. HTTPS
LLM Explanation: The data-link layer protocols in TCP/IP are responsible for delivering data over the physical network links. From the given options, Ethernet and PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) are examples of data-link layer protocols. Ethernet is commonly used in local area networks (LANs), while PPP is used for point-to-point connections, such as dial-up internet access. TCP, HTTP, SMTP, and HTTPS are higher-layer protocols that operate above the data-link layer in the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Cisco Press, 2020', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols, Kevin R. Fall, W. Richard Stevens, Addison-Wesley, 2011']

Question Text: Which of the following statements are functions of a routing protocol? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Learning routes and putting those routes into the routing table for routes advertised to the router by its neighboring routers
b. Advertising known routes to neighboring routers
c. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router
d. Forwarding IP packets based on a packetâ€™s destination IP address
LLM Explanation: The main functions of a routing protocol are to learn routes from neighboring routers and advertise known routes to those neighbors. Routing protocols share routing information to build and maintain routing tables. Directly connected routes are added to the routing table when interfaces are configured and activated on the router, not through routing protocols. Forwarding IP packets based on the destination address is a function of the router itself, using the information in the routing table, but is not a direct function of the routing protocol.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 16: IP Routing Concepts', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13769-5.html']

Question Text: When you open a web browser and type in the hostname www.examsdigest.com, your computer does not send an IP packet with a destination IP address www.examsdigest.com; it sends an IP packet to an IP address used by the web server for Examsdigest. TCP/IP needs a way to let a computer find the IP address used by the listed hostname. That method uses the Domain Name System (DNS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. When a user types a hostname like www.examsdigest.com into a web browser, the computer does not directly send IP packets to that hostname. Instead, it first uses the Domain Name System (DNS) to resolve the hostname to the corresponding IP address of the web server hosting the website. Once the IP address is obtained, the computer then sends the IP packets to that resolved IP address.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 18: IP Services', 'RFC 1034 - Domain Names - Concepts and Facilities', 'RFC 1035 - Domain Names - Implementation and Specification']

Question Text: A __________________ address is an address that enables transmission to every node in a local network.
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Multicast
c. Unicast
d. MAC
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to transmit data to every node on a local network segment. It allows a single packet to be sent to all devices simultaneously. Multicast addresses are used to send data to a specific subset of nodes, unicast addresses target a single specific node, and MAC addresses are unique hardware identifiers assigned to each network interface.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: TCP and ______________ are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols.
Choices:
a. UDP
b. HTTP
c. DNS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is the correct answer. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP are the two most commonly used transport layer protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite. TCP provides reliable, connection-oriented data delivery, while UDP provides unreliable, connectionless data delivery. HTTP, DNS, and SMTP are application layer protocols that rely on TCP or UDP for transport.
URLs: ['Kurose, J. F., & Ross, K. W. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th ed.). Pearson.', 'Forouzan, B. A. (2013). TCP/IP Protocol Suite (4th ed.). McGraw-Hill Education.', 'RFC 793 - Transmission Control Protocol. (1981). IETF. https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc793', 'RFC 768 - User Datagram Protocol. (1980). IETF. https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc768']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Frame Check Sequence (FCS) field in the Ethernet frame trailer provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine if the frame experienced transmission errors. The FCS contains a 4-byte cyclic redundancy check (CRC) value calculated by the sending device. The receiving device recalculates the CRC and compares it to the value in the FCS field. If they match, the frame is considered error-free. If they differ, the frame is discarded due to transmission errors.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet']
